title: Arsonist who torched flats and car parks in Spice-fuelled rampage says 'I wanted to get nicked' - Manchester Evening News
text:

A drug addict who sparked terror by starting a fire which engulfed a city centre apartment block in the middle of the night has been jailed. 
Gerard Connor, 43, started a blaze in the underground car park of The Cube apartments in Ancoats leading it to be evacuated and causing more than a quarter of a million pounds of damage, a court heard. 
It was one of three fires crazed Connor, who said he was high on the drug Spice, lit in three separate car parks in less than two hours. Read More 
Now he has been locked up for seven years by a judge who said he had created “a real and grave risk of death” to those sleeping in the flats above. Gerard Connor, 43, was jailed for three counts of arson 
His arson spree began at the apartment block, on Advent Way, on the outskirts of the city centre in the early hours of Friday October 28. 
Connor got into the basement car park of the fully occupied block, which contains 32 two-bedroom apartments and was seen on CCTV at around 1am. 
He was carrying a plastic bag containing lighters, combustible materials and possibly even an accelerant such as petrol, the court was told. The scene of the fire at The Cube on Advent Way, Ancoats 
It is believed he started the fire either underneath or in the grill of a black Ford Focus belonging to one of the residents. 
At around 1.40am residents were woken from their beds by smoke alarms going off on the second floor of the six-storey building. Read More Should GMP have stopped 'Britain's Josef Fritzl' 25 YEARS before he was finally convicted? 
Firefighters raced to the scene and evacuated the entire building with more than six fire engines involved in tackling the flames, which destroyed three cars and spread to the wooden floor boards above the car park and up a stairwell or shaft to the upper floors. The entire building was evacuated after residents were woken by fire alarms at around 1.40am 
Flames also lapped up the side of the building and the court was shown photographs of huge black scorch marks on the exterior of the building, also captured by the M.E.N the following morning. 
Thankfully no one was injured but an estimated £250,000 worth of damage was caused to the building, Simone Flynn prosecuting said. Read More 
He also lit two more fires that night in two other city centre car parks. The scene of the fire in the car park of the Ancoats flats 
Shortly before 3am a small blaze was started underneath a plastic cleaning sign at the NCP car park on Chatham Street. 
Connor was seen on CCTV kneeling down and using items from his plastic bag to start it and he sat and watched it melt the sign and burn the floor around it before fleeing. 
Then at around 3.20am he torched a Fiat 500 in the NCP car park on Whitworth Street causing it to explode and leaving the motor worth £5,500 a complete write-off. 
The car park was open at the time and “anyone stood nearby or returning to their car could have been walked into the field of the blast” Mrs Flynn said. One of the other fires started by Connor on the same night - at the NCP car park on the corner of Chatham Street and Piccadilly 
Connor, a habitual thief with 80 previous convictions, was identified and linked to all the offences after a police officer recognised him from the CCTV footage. 
Connor, of no fixed abode, initially denied starting the blaze at The Cube when he was arrested the following day. 
However he pleaded guilty to three counts of Arson being reckless as to whether life was endangered at Manchester Crown Square on Friday. The fire Connor started in the basement of the Palace Theatre car park 
He also admitted the theft of two cars a fortnight before the fires, a Ford Focus from the driveway of a house in Beswick, and a £7,000 Vauxhall Astra from the same car park at the Cube where he started the huge blaze. The vehicle was found abandoned nearby a short time later. 
Cannabis and heroin addict Connor told officers on his arrest after the fires that he “wanted to get nicked” as he was sick of living on the streets after coming out of prison just weeks earlier. 
However he now says he was high on a mixture of alcohol and the potent former legal high and now banned substance Spice. Read More 
Joe Rawlings defending, said: “It was a case of intoxication of some kind and anger at his current circumstances. 
“There does appear to be genuine remorse. 
“In his words, he could have killed someone, so he at least accepts that.” Connor's defence said 'there does appear to be genuine remorse' 
Sentencing him to seven years behind bars, with an extended four year licence, Judge Richard Mansell QC told him: “The photographs showing the damage are quite shocking. 
“And it is extremely fortunate, not only for the residents but also for you that you are not facing charges of manslaughter today. 
“One can only imagine the terror those residents felt when they were woken from their beds and told they must evacuate. 
“You created a real and grave risk of death to those residents. 
“Your motivation for these crimes is not clear. 
“If, as I suspect, you did this to try and get yourself locked up you did it such a way that you showed no regard not only to your own safety but also to that of others.” Like us on Facebook
